comments.commentBody: You get what you pay for. Cheap and convenient vs. safety and security; the latter is more appealing to me and worth the extra cost.

Good for Uber. The only people these authorities are "protecting" are the taxi and limo companies. And it's their poor service and high prices that led to Uber in the first place. Our tax dollars should protect them?

The cab companies need to reinvent themselves by lowering costs to compete with the competition. Their image would be more favorable if they hired military veterans who need jobs. Red, White and Blue cabs with the "Ride American" motto would be a good start.

Ask anyone dependent upon local transportation that has used both taxis and a ridesarhing service which would they prefer. Undoubtedly the answer would be a ridesarhing service. Uber has unleashed the spirit of the individual and non goverment control service.
Think about this, the government controlled taxi medallions were issued to prevent shoddy cars and service, unscrupulous drivers over charging and harassing passengers and to control market price by controlling the amount of cars in the service area.
Do you think that is what you get from taxis? Not at all. If anything, quite the opposite.
Do you you get clean, efficient and courtesy service from ride-sharing services? Yes, yes and yes.
Let's let service providers and users determine how things get done without ineffective government controls that add consumer costs and costly and burdensome to service provider. Let the free market breath!

Witch Hunt? Maybe. Maybe not. But what goes around comes back around. It seems Mr Trump began this game with the Obama birth certificate nonsense. Then there was the Congressional Benghazi hullabaloo. Then Hillary's e-mail inquiries. Should the Democrats now just sit back and play statesmen? The Republicans in this Congress started this mess and now that they have opened Pandora's box they must suffer the consequences of putting politics ahead of good government. Of course the Republicans' continual attacks on Hillary Clinton beginning in the last century are why we now have this Trump administration.

I've had maybe 70+ Uber rides. While in San Francisco in May 2016, I had a driver who didn't know the city, took me and my colleague quite a ways away, and was initially belligerent, and realizing a bad review was coming anyway, absolutely threatening. Reporting this to Uber and pressing the matter, I received emails telling me that it was resolved. Pushing further, eventually spoke to an offshore call center, that assured me it was resolved and sent me an email saying so. While in San Francisco in September 2016, I ended up fully accessing someone else's account while attempting to use mine. Again, contacting them with very explicit details, I received immediate emails telling me the situation was resolved (it was not). Their culture is well-known. While the vast majority of their services are fine, when something bad happens, it's bad, and they don't care.

My business goes elsewhere, and I can't say enough bad about them. Most people wouldn't use them if they realized the risks that they are exposed to.

Yes, Mr. Freeman, they are trying to play down the fact that WE are having the largest grassroots protest against their attempts to destroy democracy in America in 2540 years. Nearly 5 MILLION people, primarily women but socially conscious men as well, marched against this administration the day after the Robber Baron "installation" of The Con Don in OUR White House.

They can try to downplay it all they want. It's the only "real, true" thing happening today.

At the very least, notes of face-to-face meetings between Trump campaign/transition team officials and any representative of Russia should be turned over to the Senate foreign relations committee. Intelligence agencies know what was said in telephone calls such as those between Flynn and the Russian ambassador, but we need to know what was discussed in the meetings since none of the American participants seems to have a clear recollection of their conversations. Mr. Trump can protest and feel besieged by these questionns about his Russian connections, but it was he who opened this door by encouraging the Russians to hack Clinton, by his references to information coming from the Wikileaks/Russian hack, by his lying that no one on his team had a Russian connection, by his refusal to admit that Russia was involved in the election, and by not releasing his income tax records.
What a continuing horrifying spectacle ... drip by drip, hammer blow by hammer blow, we're witnessing a veritable huge trump train wreck in progress unfolding daily before our very eyes!
In exactly what way is the public being protected, as the Portland mayor claims, by the city's efforts to crack down on a ride service that, as it turns out, is a great favorite with the public?

Well, for one thing, anything that happens to you is a problem for you and, no doubt, the driver. Uber is not legally responsible for the actions of the driver, is not obligated to provide any equipment or to maintain it, or to provide any passenger or any driver with insurance.

You're no better off than thumbing a ride.

I was "Naticked" at SCUT and NEUER. Also filled INTHELINEOFFIRE, which held me up for a while. REV before GIN. Lots of other false steps. I did a little cheating because Wait Wait Don't Tell me comes on at eleven and requires my full attention.

So SCUT is a proper name! I always fall asleep during that movie (too much rum in the eggnog?). Do we now need a special term for a Natick that isn't clued as such? Scuttled is all I can think of right now, have a puppy play date in, hmmm... about zero minutes. To Barry: PECS saved me also.

I think those of us who have been the victim of the Scut Farkases of the world have a special place in our hearts for those scenes in "A Christmas Story."
I always enjoyed that his family name (Farkas) is the Hungarian for "wolf," entirely fitting.

Which leads me to the serendipitous observation that Pécs is one of the major cities of Hungary...

.
For Suzy M. and any other sophisticates,

Wait, Wait ... is pre-recorded many weeks. Segments are posted to the Web as early as possible. Once all the segments are posted other than Lightning Fill in the Blank and the closing credits, it's safe to start listening.

Eventually, the episode is posted in its entirety.

I too listen religously at 11, but it's nice to know that if the puzzle is too hard, I can catch up on the show later.

Is it OK that I'm in love with Faith Sailie AND Kyrie O'Connor AND Roxanne Roberts? I'd "Ask Amy" Dickinson about that, but I'm in love with her too. I became acquainted over social media with a department head in the administration of the Washington Post; my parents moved to the town where she grew up, and her favorite HS teacher was the mother of one of my closest teenage friends.

Also, a friend got a job with the Post.

I really want to ask what Roxanne Roberts is like in person but somehow it seems wrong.

Bottom line: Trump has GOT to make his tax returns public.  All of this back-and-forth about Russian contacts means little until we can see whether the Russians have implanted a significant financial stake in Trump's enterprises.  Trumps' tax returns would settle almost all of this hubbub immediately I think.
I don't think smooching with the enemy  is routine campaigning.  Let alone have the enemy endorse you!  Nothing normal about this situation.

It isn't the contacts alone, it's the lying, deceiving, and perjury used to cover them up.  The context makes it worse, when the hacking of the DNC started and there were suspicions it was led by Russians, Donald Trump didn't think that an attack on part of the system was an attack on the whole system, he openly encouraged it.
Although SCUT is not a proper name, so I suppose I should say I was "scuttled."

At worst, the Yemen attack was a Bay of Pigs fiasco that was left to him, which he failed to stop.

That is not a fair attack from those who left it to him.

Also, nuclear use was not confined to ideas coming from Trump. That accusation comes from those who were themselves presenting that very danger, using language that was at least as reckless in support of policies far more reckless, people with a history of failures by half considered overreaching such as Libya, Syria, and Ukraine.

This complaint aimed at Trump is purely partisan, coming from those with that in their own background.

I'd rather we urge caution, and a diplomatic approach via outreach, which is exactly what the anti-Trump attacks seem designed to prevent.

That is not to suggest Trump is any paragon. We've hit bottom after dodging the worst bullet. Now we need to crawl out, and it will be a long crawl requiring far better from people less compromised.

One would think that the Trump Team would have rushed out a schedule showing all the other countries that they had multiple contacts with last year, as a means to minimize the impact of these Russian meetings. That this list hasn't been produced makes the Russian encounters even more suspicious.

" In response, 100,000 protesters descended on the Capitol, while others protested at the executive residence and even my house.

Despite the intimidation......"

The Sarah Palin victim card. Well played, Governor!

Scott Walker is writing pure propaganda.  Why does the NYT publish this kind of thing without fact checking it?  Is it now so acceptable to tell brazen lies on the NYT Op-Ed page?  And Jeff Sessions is not lying...

I'm so happy for you… You took away bargaining rights rahter than bargain.
Lowered standards of living for thousands. weakened a great education system all the way through college. There was more done, but some people and coorporations pay less tax. And you get your raise your, health insurance. your lifetime paycheck.. So brave or so cold or so shortsighted … I'm so happy for you.
NO, Mr. Walker. Just NO.
Yasser Taima – I do so hope you include those of the Blue States on the 'third Coast.'
Where have you been?.....these GOP KOCH BROTHER CLOWNS  have destroyed our country's values while dupping half the country  to support them sorta like a "political battered wife syndrome"!!!!!!!
Maybe you haven't read his other comments?

Turn healthcare back to the states? Because it was working so well prior to the ACA? And how about that Governor Sam Brownback in Kansas? The results of his governing using GOP Dogma has sure worked out well for the residents of that state.
